catalogue_claim.location_claimed: paper surface throughout; margins described as zerefshan in notes
catalogue_claim.exact_text: Aharlı nohudi renkli, yaldız serpmeli, yaldız cetvelli, yatay su yolu çizgili

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p003 shows front flyleaf with ownership inscriptions (III. Osman tugrali vakif muhru visible). p007 shows a regular text folio with clear two-page opening in talik script.

evidence.observation: Dense gold particles clearly and unambiguously visible across the entire paper surface. The warm golden tone of the paper is distinctly different from plain cream/white paper. Individual gold particles are distinguishable as fine speckled texture under the talik script. Gold ruling lines (yaldız cetvel) also clearly visible framing the text block. Paper color matches catalogue description of 'nohudi' (chickpea/beige).

limitations: Only 2 of 229 pages examined; sprinkling confirmed as uniform across at least one text folio
Margin zerefshan (noted in genel_notlar as 'sahife kenarlar zerefsan') was not separately distinguishable at this zoom level from the overall paper sprinkling
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Confirmed. Pass to motif-classifier for deeper analysis. Consider examining the marginal areas at higher zoom to assess whether the zerefshan margins are distinguishable from the paper serpme.

catalogue_claim.location_claimed: partial -- 'yapraklarin bazi yerlerinde' (on some parts of the leaves)
catalogue_claim.exact_text: Âharlı, suyolu yatay ve dikey, yaprakların bazı yerlerinde gümüş yaldız serpmeli, orta kalınlıkta, nohudî renkli kâğıt

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p010 shows a two-page text opening in the risale section. p010_zoom is the same folio at higher zoom. The risale occupies approx. ff. 5-20 within the 121-page mecmua digitization.

evidence.observation: Two-page opening visible. Left page has warm cream tone; right page has noticeably cooler, greyer tone — consistent with a silver-sprinkled leaf (silver particles scatter light differently from gold, giving a cooler tone; tarnished silver appears as dark grey specks). This tonal contrast between pages supports the catalogue claim of partial sprinkling ('bazı yerlerinde').

Zoomed view confirms tonal difference between left (warm cream) and right (cooler, darker grey) pages. Right page shows granular texture in paper surface consistent with scattered metallic particles. Individual particles not distinctly resolvable as silver at this zoom level. Talik script confirmed, paper appears medium-weight as described ('orta kalınlıkta').

limitations: Silver particles tarnish over time and may appear as dark grey flecks rather than bright metallic — hard to distinguish from paper impurities at screenshot resolution
Only pages ~p010 examined; catalogue says partial ('bazı yerlerinde') so not all pages are expected to show sprinkling
Could not examine the specific folio range ff. 5-20 with full confidence about page number correspondence
Verdict 'probable' rather than 'confirmed' because individual silver particles not individually distinguishable
visual_confirmation.recommendation: High-priority for manual in-person examination or higher-resolution digital imaging. This is the only silver-sprinkled example in the serpme search results and is a rare variant. The tonal evidence supports the catalogue claim. Manual examination should focus on pages where the cooler/greyer tone is most pronounced.

limitations: Gold sprinkling less visually obvious than in 03880 at screenshot resolution — possibly finer or less dense application
Only 1 of 97 pages examined; illuminated headpiece (mentioned in notes) not yet examined

Upgrade to 'confirmed' would require examining the illuminated opening (likely pages 2-4) where the serlevha and zerefshan context would provide additional evidence, or zooming in further on the paper margins where gold particles are most visible. catalogue_claim.exact_text: Aharlı, nohudi renkli, serpme yaldızlı, yaldız cetvelli, dikey su yolu çizgili

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p002 is the binding spine (not a folio). p004 shows flyleaf with ownership inscriptions (left) and a dark burgundy/red colored endleaf with gold knot design (right). p006 shows the text opening with the illuminated serlevha (tezhibli unvan) on the right page. p007 shows a plain text folio opening.

evidence.observation: Two-page opening: left page is a flyleaf with ownership inscriptions and waqf stamps (III. Osman tugrali vakif muhru visible at bottom). Right page is a dark burgundy/vişne (cherry red) colored leaf with a gold interlaced knot design (gülbend) — this is a colored luxury endleaf. The presence of a colored endleaf is consistent with high-quality production including gold-sprinkled paper.

Illuminated serlevha (tezhibli unvan) clearly visible on the right page as catalogued ('Tezhibli Serlevha 1b sayfasında'). The headpiece is a classic Ottoman illumination with blue and gold interlace pattern and hanging pendant (salbek). Gold ruling lines (yaldız cetvel) clearly visible on both pages. Paper surface has a warm golden tone consistent with gold-sprinkled paper, but at this zoom level individual gold particles are not distinctly visible.

Regular text folio (nestalik script, Persian text). Gold ruling lines clearly visible framing text blocks. Paper has consistent warm cream/nohudi tone throughout both pages. Fine sprinkling visible as warm golden texture but individual particles not distinguishable at this zoom level.

limitations: Individual gold particles not distinctly visible at screenshot zoom level
Fine serpme application may require higher-resolution imaging to confirm unambiguously
Verdict 'probable' rather than 'confirmed' because of resolution limitation, despite strong corroborating evidence (illuminated headpiece, colored endleaf, luxury binding, reliable cataloguer)
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Probable. The illuminated serlevha, colored endleaf, and gold ruling are all confirmed. The paper sprinkling is consistent with the warm tone but not unambiguously visible. Upgrade to 'confirmed' with higher-resolution imaging or in-person examination. Pass to motif-classifier. Also note: the colored burgundy endleaf with gold knot is a codicological feature worth cataloguing separately.
